item_prototype.name: Airflow Temperature
item_prototype.description: 190 - Airflow temperature on Western Digital HDs (Same as temp. [C2], but current value is 50 less for some models. Marked as obsolete.)

item_prototype.name: Calibration Retry Count
item_prototype.description: 11 - This attribute indicates the count that recalibration was requested (under the condition that the first attempt was unsuccessful). An increase of this attribute value is a sign of problems in the hard disk mechanical subsystem.

item_prototype.name: Command Timeout
item_prototype.description: 188 - The count of aborted operations due to HDD timeout. Normally this attribute value should be equal to zero and if the value is far above zero, then most likely there will be some serious problems with power supply or an oxidized data cable.

item_prototype.name: Current Pending Sector Count
item_prototype.description: 197 - Count of "unstable" sectors (waiting to be remapped, because of unrecoverable read errors). If an unstable sector is subsequently read successfully, the sector is remapped and this value is decreased. Read errors on a sector will not remap the sector immediately (since the correct value cannot be read and so the value to remap is not known, and also it might become readable later); instead, the drive firmware remembers that the sector needs to be remapped, and will remap it the next time it's written. However some drives will not immediately remap such sectors when written; instead the drive will first attempt to write to the problem sector and if the write operation is successful then the sector will be marked good (in this case, the "Reallocation Event Count" (0xC4) will not be increased). This is a serious shortcoming, for if such a drive contains marginal sectors that consistently fail only after some time has passed following a successful write operation, then the drive will never remap these problem sectors.

item_prototype.name: Data Address Mark errors
item_prototype.description: 202 - Count of Data Address Mark errors (or vendor-specific).

item_prototype.name: End-to-End error
item_prototype.description: 184 - This attribute is a part of Hewlett-Packard's SMART IV technology, as well as part of other vendors' IO Error Detection and Correction schemas, and it contains a count of parity errors which occur in the data path to the media via the drive's cache RAM.

item_prototype.name: Hardware ECC Recovered
item_prototype.description: 195 - (Vendor-specific raw value.) The raw value has different structure for different vendors and is often not meaningful as a decimal number.

item_prototype.name: High Fly Writes
item_prototype.description: 189 - HDD manufacturers implement a flying height sensor that attempts to provide additional protections for write operations by detecting when a recording head is flying outside its normal operating range. If an unsafe fly height condition is encountered, the write process is stopped, and the information is rewritten or reallocated to a safe region of the hard drive. This attribute indicates the count of these errors detected over the lifetime of the drive. This feature is implemented in most modern Seagate drives and some of Western Digital's drives, beginning with the WD Enterprise WDE18300 and WDE9180 Ultra2 SCSI hard drives, and will be included on all future WD Enterprise products.

item_prototype.name: Load Cycle Count
item_prototype.description: 193 - Count of load/unload cycles into head landing zone position. Western Digital rates their VelociRaptor drives for 600,000 load/unload cycles, and WD Green drives for 300,000 cycles; the latter ones are designed to unload heads often to conserve power. On the other hand, the WD3000GLFS (a desktop drive) is specified for only 50,000 load/unload cycles. Some laptop drives and "green power" desktop drives are programmed to unload the heads whenever there has not been any activity for a very short period of time, such as about five seconds. Many Linux installations write to the file system a few times a minute in the background. As a result, there may be 100 or more load cycles per hour, and the load cycle rating may be exceeded in less than a year.

item_prototype.name: Multi-Zone Error Rate
item_prototype.description: 200 - The count of errors found when writing a sector. The higher the value, the worse the disk's mechanical condition is.

item_prototype.name: Offline Uncorrectable
item_prototype.description: 198 - The total count of uncorrectable errors when reading/writing a sector. A rise in the value of this attribute indicates defects of the disk surface and/or problems in the mechanical subsystem.

item_prototype.name: Power-off Retract Count
item_prototype.description: 192 - Count of times the heads are loaded off the media. Heads can be unloaded without actually powering off.

item_prototype.name: Power-On Hours (POH)
item_prototype.description: 9 - Count of hours in power-on state. The raw value of this attribute shows total count of hours (or minutes, or seconds, depending on manufacturer) in power-on state. "By default, the total expected lifetime of a hard disk in perfect condition is defined as 5 years (running every day and night on all days). This is equal to 1825 days in 24/7 mode or 43800 hours." On some pre-2005 drives, this raw value may advance erratically and/or "wrap around" (reset to zero periodically).

item_prototype.name: Power Cycle Count
item_prototype.description: 12 - This attribute indicates the count of full hard disk power on/off cycles.

item_prototype.name: Read Error Rate
item_prototype.description: 1 - (Vendor specific raw value.) Stores data related to the rate of hardware read errors that occurred when reading data from a disk surface. The raw value has different structure for different vendors and is often not meaningful as a decimal number.

item_prototype.name: Reallocated Sectors Count
item_prototype.description: 5 - Count of reallocated sectors. When the hard drive finds a read/write/verification error, it marks that sector as "reallocated" and transfers data to a special reserved area (spare area). This process is also known as remapping, and reallocated sectors are called "remaps". The raw value normally represents a count of the bad sectors that have been found and remapped. Thus, the higher the attribute value, the more sectors the drive has had to reallocate. This allows a drive with bad sectors to continue operation; however, a drive which has had any reallocations at all is significantly more likely to fail in the near future. While primarily used as a metric of the life expectancy of the drive, this number also affects performance. As the count of reallocated sectors increases, the read/write speed tends to become worse because the drive head is forced to seek to the reserved area whenever a remap is accessed. If sequential access speed is critical, the remapped sectors can be manually marked as bad blocks in the file system in order to prevent their use.

item_prototype.name: Reallocation Event Count
item_prototype.description: 196 - Count of remap operations. The raw value of this attribute shows the total count of attempts to transfer data from reallocated sectors to a spare area. Both successful & unsuccessful attempts are counted.

item_prototype.name: Reported Uncorrectable Errors
item_prototype.description: 187 - The count of errors that could not be recovered using hardware ECC (see attribute 195).

item_prototype.name: Runtime Bad Block
item_prototype.description: 183 - Western Digital, Samsung or Seagate attribute: Total number of data blocks with detected, uncorrectable errors encountered during normal operation.

item_prototype.name: Seek Error Rate
item_prototype.description: 7 - (Vendor specific raw value.) Rate of seek errors of the magnetic heads. If there is a partial failure in the mechanical positioning system, then seek errors will arise. Such a failure may be due to numerous factors, such as damage to a servo, or thermal widening of the hard disk. The raw value has different structure for different vendors and is often not meaningful as a decimal number.

item_prototype.name: Seek Time Performance
item_prototype.description: 8 - Average performance of seek operations of the magnetic heads. If this attribute is decreasing, it is a sign of problems in the mechanical subsystem.

item_prototype.name: Soft Read Error Rate
item_prototype.description: 13 - Uncorrected read errors reported to the operating system.

item_prototype.name: Spin-Up Time
item_prototype.description: 3 - Average time of spindle spin up (from zero RPM to fully operational [milliseconds]).

item_prototype.name: Spin Retry Count
item_prototype.description: 10 - Count of retry of spin start attempts. This attribute stores a total count of the spin start attempts to reach the fully operational speed (under the condition that the first attempt was unsuccessful). An increase of this attribute value is a sign of problems in the hard disk mechanical subsystem.

item_prototype.name: Start/Stop Count
item_prototype.description: 4 - A tally of spindle start/stop cycles. The spindle turns on, and hence the count is increased, both when the hard disk is turned on after having before been turned entirely off (disconnected from power source) and when the hard disk returns from having previously been put to sleep mode.

item_prototype.name: TA Counter Detected
item_prototype.description: 201 - Count of off-track errors.

item_prototype.name: Temperature
item_prototype.description: 194 - Current internal temperature.

item_prototype.name: UltraDMA CRC Error Count
item_prototype.description: 199 - The count of errors in data transfer via the interface cable as determined by ICRC (Interface Cyclic Redundancy Check).

trigger_prototype.name: S.M.A.R.T. - Command Timeout {#SHORTDISKNAME}
trigger_prototype.description: The count of aborted operations due to HDD timeout. Normally this attribute value should be equal to zero and if the value is far above zero, then most likely there will be some serious problems with power supply or an oxidized data cable.

trigger_prototype.name: S.M.A.R.T. - Current Pending Sector Count {#SHORTDISKNAME}
trigger_prototype.description: Count of "unstable" sectors (waiting to be remapped, because of unrecoverable read errors). If an unstable sector is subsequently read successfully, the sector is remapped and this value is decreased. Read errors on a sector will not remap the sector immediately (since the correct value cannot be read and so the value to remap is not known, and also it might become readable later); instead, the drive firmware remembers that the sector needs to be remapped, and will remap it the next time it's written. However some drives will not immediately remap such sectors when written; instead the drive will first attempt to write to the problem sector and if the write operation is successful then the sector will be marked good (in this case, the "Reallocation Event Count" (0xC4) will not be increased). This is a serious shortcoming, for if such a drive contains marginal sectors that consistently fail only after some time has passed following a successful write operation, then the drive will never remap these problem sectors.

trigger_prototype.name: S.M.A.R.T. - End-to-End error {#SHORTDISKNAME}
trigger_prototype.description: This attribute is a part of Hewlett-Packard's SMART IV technology, as well as part of other vendors' IO Error Detection and Correction schemas, and it contains a count of parity errors which occur in the data path to the media via the drive's cache RAM.

trigger_prototype.name: S.M.A.R.T. - Offline Uncorrectable {#SHORTDISKNAME}
trigger_prototype.description: The total count of uncorrectable errors when reading/writing a sector. A rise in the value of this attribute indicates defects of the disk surface and/or problems in the mechanical subsystem.

trigger_prototype.name: S.M.A.R.T. - Reallocated Sectors Count {#SHORTDISKNAME}
trigger_prototype.description: Count of reallocated sectors. When the hard drive finds a read/write/verification error, it marks that sector as "reallocated" and transfers data to a special reserved area (spare area). This process is also known as remapping, and reallocated sectors are called "remaps". The raw value normally represents a count of the bad sectors that have been found and remapped. Thus, the higher the attribute value, the more sectors the drive has had to reallocate. This allows a drive with bad sectors to continue operation; however, a drive which has had any reallocations at all is significantly more likely to fail in the near future. While primarily used as a metric of the life expectancy of the drive, this number also affects performance. As the count of reallocated sectors increases, the read/write speed tends to become worse because the drive head is forced to seek to the reserved area whenever a remap is accessed. If sequential access speed is critical, the remapped sectors can be manually marked as bad blocks in the file system in order to prevent their use.

trigger_prototype.name: S.M.A.R.T. - Reallocation Event Count {#SHORTDISKNAME}
trigger_prototype.description: Count of remap operations. The raw value of this attribute shows the total count of attempts to transfer data from reallocated sectors to a spare area. Both successful & unsuccessful attempts are counted.

trigger_prototype.name: S.M.A.R.T. - Reported Uncorrectable Errors {#SHORTDISKNAME}
trigger_prototype.description: The count of errors that could not be recovered using hardware ECC.

trigger_prototype.name: S.M.A.R.T. - Runtime Bad Block {#SHORTDISKNAME}
trigger_prototype.description: Western Digital, Samsung or Seagate attribute: Total number of data blocks with detected, uncorrectable errors encountered during normal operation.

trigger_prototype.name: S.M.A.R.T. - Spin Retry Count {#SHORTDISKNAME}
trigger_prototype.description: Count of retry of spin start attempts. This attribute stores a total count of the spin start attempts to reach the fully operational speed (under the condition that the first attempt was unsuccessful). An increase of this attribute value is a sign of problems in the hard disk mechanical subsystem.
